events.name: Hack && Tell Singapore at Zalora!
events.description: Hack && Tell is a show and tell meetup for programmers. Call for speakers is open! Submit your proposals here:  https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1BxbhFahhD4nShAPW9rtJXsS3zdN9nh2-AgbEaSvnuoM/edit?usp=drive_web --- Worked on a project that you're excited about? Encountered a mysterious bug that got you scratching your head? Or did you just learn how to use a new commandline tool that changed your life? Tell us about it! We encourage presentations of any kind on projects that people work on for fun, for the love of all things technical. The only rules are 1) no startup pitches and 2) no work projects (unless it solves a general problem and is open sourced). Talk slots are 10 minutes long (5 minutes of presentation and 5 minutes of Q&A). First-time speakers and of underrepresented groups in tech are welcome! We'd be glad to help you prepare for your talk.  --- Agenda: 6:30p - 7:00p: Dinner (will be provided)7:00p - 8:00p: Lightning Talks 8:00p - 9:00p: Meet the speakers + mingling Food: Food will be provided for dinner. Vegetarian and halal options available. Please let us know if you have any dietary or assistive needs. Getting here: A short walk from the Tanjong Pagar or Outram Park stations, and accessible by the 75, 97, 131, and 167 buses - https://www.google.com.sg/maps/place/10+Hoe+Chiang+Rd,+Singapore+089311/ Speakers and their projects:1) Yin Shanyang built an isochrone map of Singapore (https://medium.com/@yinshanyang/isochronic-singapore-a-gentle-introduction-to-isochrone-maps-9cceebc72f60). This is a talk about the head banging involved just to draw some lines on a map. 2) Saad Chinoy is going to tell us all about microbial fuel cells and how they like Star Wars' The Force in real life. Check it out: http://www.tusitalabooks.com/2017/02/21/mesmerising-microbes/ He'll also be showing us a a working tiny diy microbial fuel cell made with mud at Hack && Tell, so make sure to be there! 3) Melvin Tiong wrote a JavaScript library to parse Shell variable declarations. If parsing variable declaration syntax is 20% of the work of a shell, does this mean with 400% more effort, we can write a shell in JavaScript?? *alarm bells*. Check the library out here: https://github.com/sneakertack/nvar  4) Nan Xiao will be introducing 3 small CPU tips: endianness, byte-alignment and stack growth, and why it might be important for you to know as a programmer! Check a sneak peek out here: https://github.com/NanXiao/cpu-tips. Nan Xiao's website: http://nanxiao.me/en/ 5) Smit Shah, who build a live-streaming library! It's a two-way channel, so bring your digital device with a webcam and browser to join in the demo!Link to the project: https://github.com/shah-smit/live-stream-hackSmit's profile: https://github.com/shah-smit
events.location: Zalora Singapore Office, Keppel Towers , 10 Hoe Chiang Road, #18-01, 089315

events.name: Ethereum Foundation: Zahoor Mohamed Swarm
events.description:
Swarm is a distributed storage platform and content distribution service, a native base layer service of the ethereum web 3 stack. The primary objective of Swarm is to provide a decentralized and redundant store of Ethereum's public record, in particular to store and distribute dapp code and data as well as block chain data. From the end user's perspective, Swarm is not that different from WWW, except that uploads are not to a specific server. The objective is to peer-to-peer storage and serving solution that is DDOS-resistant, zero-downtime, fault-tolerant and censorship-resistant as well as self-sustaining due to a built-in incentive system which uses peer to peer accounting and allows trading resources for payment. Swarm is designed to deeply integrate with the devp2p multiprotocol network layer of Ethereum as well as with the Ethereum blockchain for domain name resolution, service payments and content availability insurance. 


Event Timeline:  6:30 - 7:00 pm : Registration + Reception 7:00 - 8:00 pm : Zahoor Mohamed's Keynote 8:00 - 8:30 pm: Q&A + Reception Website Link: http://swarm-gateways.net/bzz:/theswarm.eth/ 



Organized by DigixGlobal:   Venue sponsored by:

events.name: GoSG Meetup August 2017
events.description: Golang 1.9 is out soon. What do you know from this new release. Come to our meet up and get some tips about using Golang in your work or side project.  Agenda:  • Talk 1: "Configuring services and applications in Go", Loh Siu Yin • Talk 2: "APEX" , Kai Hendry • Talk 3: "Go Tooling", Dan Tran.  Pizza will be serve at 7pm. Thanks to Singapore Power.
events.location: Singapore Power, 240 Tanjong Pagar Road #08-00 Singapore 088540

events.name: Learning To Code With Google's Go - The Future Language of Choice (22nd August)
events.description: We will be conducting a free meetup to teach new programmers how to code using Google's Go. At the end of two hours, you will learn to write simple code in Go, compile it, and execute the program.  This lesson is targeted at new beginners who have no prior background in coding, although existing programmers in learning Go are welcomed to join in as well. As spaces are limited, priority goes to new programmers. This is a very basic course, we highly recommend it to anyone who's interested to pick up coding even if you have no prior background at all. Go is easily the future language of choice for big companies! See these articles on why you should learn go here and why it's the future. For this lesson, you must bring along your own computer (any system) and be prepared to learn how to write code and build websites! There are no other prerequisites. Don't have a computer? Pm me and I will bring one more for you. Spaces are limited for only 30 students.
events.location: Tri5 Ventures, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent #03-26, S139951, Singapore

events.name: Security & Continuous Delivery
events.description:
In this talk, we will share our lessons learned when discussing Continuous Delivery with security teams. This includes scenarios and concerns that are raised, and how we help security teams be part of the Continuous Delivery process rather than blockers to it. • Moving away from Code Review • Addressing the risks of automated environments • Should production deployments be automated? • Accessing production databases and logs for troubleshooting 


About the speaker:Sriram "Ram" Narayanan is a Principal Consultant with 23 years of experience in the IT field. He has spend the past 12 years at ThoughtWorks with the good fortune to have played the various roles of developer, architect, Infrastructure Engineer, and Build and Release engineer. He has worked with clients across the world in the domains of banking, insurance, e-commerce, government services and retail. Along the way, he has made mistakes and learned from them. Today, he advises customers on how to deliver software reliably, on time and by managing budgets well. Ram has presented in the past at the DevSecCon, the DevOpsDays, and the Global Scrum alliance. He is working on a book on Security and Continuous Delivery based on everyday lessons.
events.location: ThoughtWorks , 18 cross street #11-08 China Sq Central (S)048423, Singapore
